US Tsubaki

RMP/PSM Program

EPA #1000 0017 3732



1.0    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The executive summary provides an overview of the facility specific information that was generated during the development of the RMP including but not limited to storage quantities, hazard assessment data, training dates, Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) dates, etc.  

U.S. Tsubaki (UST) stores up to 24,264 pounds of propane at the 106 Lonczak Drive, Chicopee Massachusetts site in its 6,565-gallon propane storage tank. UST is required to address the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) Regulation 40 CFR 68 and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation 29 CFR 1910.119 because UST exceeds the 10,000 pound propane threshold.

The RMP electronic submittal form was submitted and reviewed by EPA on December 19, 2000 and must be re-submitted to the EPA within five years of the initial submission or sooner under the following conditions:

* No later than three years after a newly regulated substance is first listed by EPA;

* No later than the date on which a new regulated substances is first present in an already covered process above a threshold quantity;

* No later than the date on which a regulated substance is first present above a threshold quantity in a new process;

* Within six months of a change that requires a revised PHA;

* Within six months of a change that requires a revised offsite consequence analysis and defined as a decrease/increase to endpoint by a factor of two; and

* Within six months of a change that alters the program level that applied to any covered process.

    Note:    If a facility is no longer subject to the regulation, the owner or operator shall re-submit a revised registration to EPA within six months indicating that the facility is no longer covered.

Tighe & Bond revised the inspection date, executive summary, and off-site consequence analysis based on the latitu

es for the facility;

* Oversee other programs as necessary to document compliance; and

* Maintains current written programs for each RMP requirement and reviews, each program annually, at a minimum.

3.0 HAZARD ASSESSMENT

As discussed in section 1.0, the hazard assessment is periodically reviewed and re-submitted to the EPA as necessary.  This hazard assessment also includes maps that delineate the off-site consequence (OCA) analysis.  The OCA analysis has not been included in this executive summary in accordance with EPA restrictions.

This OCA information has been provided to the general public (e.g. Local/State Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) and the local fire department/HAZMAT response team) through correspondence dated August 9, 2000 and a public meeting held on September 5, 2000.  The local agencies also receive a copy of the emergency response plan (periodically upon updating) and Tier II forms (annually).  Emergency personnel also tour the facility periodically to familiarize themselves with chemical hazards at UST.  The OCA was updated based on revised latitude measurements supplied by EPA during a September 1, 2004 inspection.  This updated information will be provided to local emergency personnel.

4.0 PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION 

Important health and safety information are readily available for the chemical and processes for a variety of reasons (e.g., emergencies, equipment maintenance, etc.).  A listing of the information is included in Section 4.4 of the RMP.

A significant amount of this information can be found primarily throughout the RMP document.  A separate process safety file is maintained for RMP documentation at the Facility. This includes the equipment manuals for the Japanese furnaces that have been translated into English. 

5.0 PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS 

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed at the facility and is included in Section 5.5 of the RMP.  Appropriate facility employees and outside Consultants were involved in t

his process.  The following participants conducted the initial PHA under this program on June 27, 2000:

U.S. Tsubaki
Tighe & Bond
Contractors
* Peter Mushovic

* Les Zielinski
* Michael Matilainen

* Adam Lomartire
* E. Osterman Propane



- Bill Murray



- Richard Dannel


In addition, Tighe & Bond and UST met with the propane supplier (Ostermans) on October 22, 2003 to discuss additional safety issues with the propane system.  A number of PHA items have been completed since December 2000.  These are designated as ?Action Complete? or ?AC?. Several other items will be addressed in accordance with recommended time frames.

6.0 OPERATING INSTRUCTIONS 

Standard Operating procedures either existed or were developed for the facility.  These include programs such as lockout/tagout, confined space, hot work permit, propane procedures, etc.  A number of these programs have standard operating procedures and checklist that are requisite for documenting regulatory compliance, particularly for the regulated propane process.  The instructions for completion of the forms are included in the RMP document.  UST completes these (or equivalent) forms and maintains documentation in the facility files.  

Tighe & Bond personnel visited the facility on June 18, 2000 to investigate and document standard operating procedures for the hardening furnaces.  Operators at the facility reviewed and commented on draft procedures developed by Tighe & Bond.  The Operators? comments are included in the final procedures incorporated into this Risk Management Plan.  The operating procedures were reviewed by the RMPC prior to implementation and are reviewed annually thereafter.  The revisions are incorporated into the RMP document.  The page header and the cover page of the RMP document are updated to show the last revision date.



7.0 TRAINING

Individuals who work on the process at the facility have been provided specific training on the hazards of the process as well as the safe and proper oper

ating procedures.  Individuals who have been certified in the process are included in the training certification documentation found in Section 7.0 of the RMP.  Any new employees who are expected to operate or work on this process are provided specific operational training and included in the training certification list.

Initial regulatory training was provided on May 30, 2000.  Additional propane hazard and emergency response training was performed on June 27, 2000.  Implementation training was performed around December 2000.  The training outlines and evaluation quizzes can be found in the facility?s Process Safety file.  The operators and other personnel were provided their three-year refresher training on propane system operations on September 30, 2003 and January 20, 2004.  

8.0 MECHANICAL INTEGRITY  

The facility ensures the integrity of process equipment by determining that the equipment is maintained, designed, installed and operating properly.  The primary emphasis behind mechanical integrity is preventative maintenance.  The majority of process equipment has standard operating manuals and maintenance procedures that are kept in the office file.

The facility ensures that recommended maintenance is performed on process equipment in accordance with manufacturer?s recommendations.  In addition, modifications to existing systems are performed in accordance with manufacturer?s recommendations.  

UST certifies that the propane system was designed in accordance with recognized engineering standards at the time of original construction and during subsequent renovations or modifications.  The propane system was inspected during the Process Hazard Analysis.  UST follows the manufacturer?s recommendations for maintenance and inspection.

Ostermans leases the tank to UST and maintains the propane system and equipment on an annual basis.  Work orders and inspection checklist for the annual work are maintained as documentation of Osterman?s propane system maintenanc

e. 

9.0    MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE 

The facility has established and implemented written procedures to manage any change to the facility or to the process chemicals (e.g., introduction of new chemicals).  This procedure is implemented by using the Management of Change forms (MOC) found in Section 9.5 of the RMP.  

These forms provide a system that evaluates potential changes to the system and potential effects on the process safety operation.  The forms must be completed any time there is a change to the process that could affect the overall safety of the chemical system.  All RMPC designees are familiar with this process.

Since December 2000, there have been minor changes to the system to include the addition of one generator identical to the two existing generators.  The plan has been updated accordingly. Operating procedures for the new generator are identical to procedures for the existing generators.

10.0    PRE-START SAFETY REVIEW 

The facility performs a pre-startup safety review for new or modified facilities as necessary.  The checklist found in Section 5 (PHA) of the RMP provides the necessary information to review and evaluate potential modifications to the existing process.  This process is started as soon as possible in the conceptual design of the project.

If there are any renovations or facility changes that would impact the process systems, it is required that the forms found in Section 10.4 (Action Item Documentation) of the RMP be completed and that any action items be incorporated into the project.  Appropriate changes may also be necessary in standard operating procedures (e.g. lockout/tagout, emergency plan, operating procedures, etc.).  These can be made through Section 9 (Management of Change Procedure) of the RMP.

Since December 2000, there have been no significant changes that would require Pre-Start-Up Safety Reviews.

11.0    COMPLIANCE AUDITS 

Comprehensive compliance audits must be performed at least every three years, while some specific p

rograms (e.g., operating procedures, lockout/tagout, etc.) should be reviewed annually by the RMPC or his designees.  The facility reportedly reviews these latter programs during annual training activities.  We have provided a summary of our recommendations for our September 30, 2003 audit that are detailed in the Tighe & Bond correspondence dated January 20, 2004.  

12.0    INCIDENT INVESTIGATION 

The facility must investigate every incident that results in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a catastrophic release of highly hazardous chemicals within 48 hours of the incident.  We recommend that all accidents be investigated.  The standard investigation system for evaluating these types of accidents is included in Section 12.4 of the RMP.  This includes an investigation form that must be completed at the time of the accident.

Upon completion of this activity, a group of individuals should investigate and determine why the accident took place.  Recommendations for corrective actions should be provided, implemented, and documented.  This should minimize the potential for reoccurrence of future similar accidents.

Since December 2000, there have been no reportable incidents at the facility relative to the propane system. There was a minor issue with the vaporizer pilot light shutting off. This minor problem has reportedly been corrected by reinstallation of the damaged vaporizer door.



13.0    EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Employees are one of the key components in safety management systems.  The facility involves employees for the implementation of this plan as follows:

* Employees are involved in safety procedure development and the PHA;

* Employees are provided periodic training at regular safety meetings;

* Safety meetings empower employees to recommend and implement corrective actions; and 

* A process has been implemented to consider employee recommendations.

Employee recommendations are incorporated into H&S procedures, where applicable.  

14.0    HOT WORK PERMI

TS 

This system provides a process whereby each heat producing work activity is evaluated and controlled to prevent fires.  Efforts are made to ensure that the entire facility completes hot work permits if the activity is outside a dedicated fire protected areas (e.g. shop).  This will minimize the potential for catastrophic fires that could affect the propane process.  The instruction and permits can be found in Section 14.0 of the RMP.  The hot work permits are on file for work performed in the facility.

15.0    CONTRACTORS

The facility must inform contract employers of the potential hazards of the process and ensure that they are properly trained.  Before working in and around hazardous processes, these contractors are provided the facility?s safety requirements and notification forms found in Section 15.0 of the RMP.  

Contractor evaluation forms were sent to Ostermans.  Completed evaluation forms can be found at the end of the CONTRACTOR SAFETY Section 15.0.  Additional evaluation forms were also sent to the following contractors:

    - Accurate Mechanical
    - Lucier Rigging
    - W.H. Park
    - Collins Electric
    - Praxair
    - Maybury










16.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  

Employers must establish and implement a plan that deals with emergency situations at the facility to include the handling of small chemical releases.  A standard emergency evacuation plan is available for the facility in the EMS-007 Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan.  It should be noted that specific propane emergency measures can also be found in the operating procedures in Section 6.0 of the RMP.

This information has been provided to the general public (e.g. Local/State Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) and the local fire department/HAZMAT response team) through correspondence dated August 9, 2000 and the public meeting held on September 5, 2000.  The local agencies also receive a copy of the emergency response plan (periodically upon updating) and Tier II forms (annually).  Emerg

ency personnel also tour the facility periodically to familiarize themselves with chemical hazards at UST.  The plant regularly performs emergency drills.

17.0 TRADE SECRETS 

The RMP provides for protection of trade secrets incidental to the process.  The facility currently has no trade secrets that have been disclosed and, therefore, does not require compliance with this particular area of the standard.
